Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Fluent \Flu"ent\, n. 1. A current of water; a stream. [Obs.] [1913 Webster]
2. [Cf. F. fluente.] (Math.) A variable quantity, considered as increasing or diminishing; -- called, in the modern calculus, the {function} or {integral}. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Fluent \Flu"ent\, a. [L. fluens, -entis, p. pr. of fluere to flow; cf. Gr. ? to boil over. Cf. {Fluctuate}, {Flux}.] 1. Flowing or capable of flowing; liquid; glodding; easily moving. [1913 Webster]
2. Ready in the use of words; voluble; copious; having words at command; and uttering them with facility and smoothness; as, a fluent speaker; hence, flowing; voluble; smooth; -- said of language; as, fluent speech. [1913 Webster]
With most fluent utterance. --Denham. [1913 Webster]
Fluent as the flight of a swallow is the sultan's letter. --De Quincey. [1913 Webster]

fluent adj 1: easy and graceful in shape; "a yacht with long, fluent curves" 2: smooth and unconstrained in movement; "a long, smooth stride"; "the fluid motion of a cat"; "the liquid grace of a ballerina"; "liquid prose" [syn: {flowing}, {fluid}, {liquid}, {smooth}] 3: expressing yourself readily, clearly, effectively; "able to dazzle with his facile tongue"; "silver speech" [syn: {eloquent}, {facile}, {silver}, {silver-tongued}, {smooth-spoken}]
